results.title: Dairying: space and system
results.creator_credit: James Coffey, Meg Stewart, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Questioning the viability of marginal dairy farming this film examines the various factors involved in assessing this industry as a spatial system. It argues the importance of the relationship of the dairy farm with the wider community at different levels, suggests changes which might benefit the industry and community as a whole and finally it asks how long marginal dairy farming can survive.

results.title: Austinmere wheat and sheep farm
results.creator_credit: Edwin Moses, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Geography”.
Views the life, work, seasonal operations, problems and uncertain outlook of an integrated wheat and sheep farm in the central west of New South Wales. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Gill Armstrong
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Film Makers”.
Michael Carlton interviews Australian film-maker Gillian Armstrong about her motivations for making films, and discusses some of her productions, in particular “My brilliant career”.

results.title: Populations
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Ecology Series”.
Describes most of the principles that cause animal and plant populations to look and behave as they do. Notes the constant change of populations, why this happens and how plants and animals take steps to ensure their survival. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Ecosystems and interactions
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Ecology Series”.
Describes the communities of organisms in ecosystems and explains how they interact with one another and the environment in which they live. Ecosystems are inescapably locked together through nutrient cycles and food chains with a common denominator - the sun - as a source of all energy

results.title: Communities
results.creator_credit: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Ecology Series”.
Reveals the structure and composition of a rain forest. Displays a myriad of populations living in conjunction with one another as the “rain forest community”. Examines the way the community functions, the factors that cause change, and the way all life is tied to the community structure.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David E. Barrow, Malcolm Otton and Film Australia

results.title: Bruce Dawe
results.creator_credit: Linda Kruger, Robin Hughes, SBS-TV and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
An intimate encounter with the extraordinary “poet of suburbia”, Bruce Dawe, whose ability to evoke the drama and beauty of everyday life has set him amongst the most accessible and highly regarded of Australian poets. His highly empathic style of writing stems from a staggered history of variant occupations, contact with those from a diversity of backgrounds and failed studies as he drifted through his early years with a skill for writing but little direction. Here his motivations and writing process as they have since stood are explored. He discusses his family history and early life, his fascinations and motivations and his view of his place in the poetry world of giving a voice to ordinary Australians. Through interviews with Dawe, footage of him reading his poetry and commentary on his life and writing this is a comprehensive personal insight into Bruce Dawe’s life and influences.
